title: How to Get TetherPro to Work with Older Digital Cameras

steps.headline: Start the software.
steps.description: Its icon looks like the tiny icon you see in reference to USB ports.

steps.headline: When you first open it, the Options dialog will come up.
steps.description: Be sure it is on Connectivity.

steps.headline: Press Connect.
steps.description: TetherPro will try to find your camera.

steps.headline: If this doesn't happen, do the easiest and quickest fix first.
steps.description: Check your battery. If it is running low, it won't work.

steps.headline: Next, change USB plug in locations.
Replace the USB cord that you are using.
Be sure that the camera isn't full of images already.
Be sure that your menu settings are set to enable you to read through the USB.
steps.description: That is in your Set Up Menu (wrench for the Nikon).

steps.headline: Check the type of camera that you have (for Nikon and Canon), or one of the other options that you think might work.
If you have notice that you don't have (or it's out of date) the MSVCR100.DLL, then go to MicroSoft and fix that.
Start taking your shots.
steps.description: At this point, it should be working.

text: Start the software. Its icon looks like the tiny icon you see in reference to USB ports. When you first open it, the Options dialog will come up. Be sure it is on Connectivity. Press Connect. TetherPro will try to find your camera. If this doesn't happen, do the easiest and quickest fix first. Check your battery. If it is running low, it won't work. Next, change USB plug in locations.  Replace the USB cord that you are using.  Be sure that the camera isn't full of images already. That can overwhelm your connection. Be sure that your menu settings are set to enable you to read through the USB. That is in your Set Up Menu (wrench for the Nikon). Check the type of camera that you have (for Nikon and Canon), or one of the other options that you think might work.  If you have notice that you don't have (or it's out of date) the MSVCR100.DLL, then go to MicroSoft and fix that. You will need to reboot. Start taking your shots. At this point, it should be working.
